definitions: medical condition involving inability to control bladder or bowel movements
general lack of self-control or restraint in behavior or habits
examples: The elderly patient struggled with incontinence after her stroke
Stress incontinence affects many women after childbirth complications
His emotional incontinence made professional meetings uncomfortable and awkward
The critic condemned the writer's verbal incontinence in overlong passages

definitions: state of trouble or difficulty caused by lack of ease or comfort
something that causes minor trouble or difficulty in daily activities
examples: The road closure caused major inconvenience for local residents
We apologize for any inconvenience during the renovation period
The broken elevator was a serious inconvenience for elderly tenants
Having to change trains twice is a minor inconvenience really

definitions: legal process of forming a corporation or company with limited liability
act of including something as part of a whole or system
examples: The incorporation of their startup took several weeks to complete
Delaware remains popular for business incorporation due to favorable laws
The incorporation of new technologies improved overall system efficiency considerably
Teachers discussed the incorporation of multimedia content into lesson plans

definitions: process of becoming greater in size, amount, or degree over time
specific amount or percentage by which something grows or rises
examples: The steady increase in housing prices worried first-time buyers everywhere
Scientists observed an increase in global temperatures over recent decades
Workers received a five percent increase in their annual salaries
The tax increase will fund essential infrastructure improvement projects statewide

definitions: small positive change in a variable or measurable quantity
fixed amount added regularly, especially to salary or payment
examples: The program counts in increments of ten for easier calculation
Temperature rises in small increments throughout the morning hours
Annual salary increments depend on performance evaluations and company profits
The loan repayment increments were set at monthly intervals initially

definitions: act of accusing someone of a crime or making them appear guilty
process of providing evidence that suggests one's own guilt in wrongdoing
examples: The witness feared incrimination of innocent people through false testimony
Police must avoid methods that lead to wrongful incrimination procedures
The Fifth Amendment protects against forced self-incrimination in criminal proceedings
Her diary entries led to her incrimination in the fraud

definitions: process of keeping eggs warm until they hatch naturally
period between infection and appearance of symptoms in disease
early stage support and development of startup businesses or ideas
examples: The incubation period for chicken eggs lasts approximately twenty-one days
Temperature control during incubation affects hatchling survival rates significantly
The incubation period for influenza typically ranges from one to four days
Some viruses have long incubation periods before symptoms appear
The tech startup thrived during its incubation at the accelerator
University incubation programs help students launch successful business ventures

definitions: enclosed apparatus providing controlled environment for premature infants
device maintaining optimal temperature and humidity for hatching eggs
facility providing resources and support for startup company development
examples: The premature twins spent three weeks in hospital incubators
Modern incubators monitor oxygen levels and infant vital signs continuously
The farmer invested in automatic incubators for the poultry operation
Temperature fluctuations in the incubator can harm developing embryos
Several successful companies emerged from that Silicon Valley incubator
The university incubator provides mentoring and seed funding opportunities

definitions: period during which someone holds an official position or office
state of being morally or legally obligated to do something
examples: During his incumbency, the mayor implemented several urban renewal projects
The senator's incumbency lasted three full terms before retirement
The incumbency of maintaining property standards falls on landlords primarily
Religious incumbency requires regular attendance at community worship services

definitions: person currently holding an official position or political office
necessary as a duty or responsibility upon someone
examples: The incumbent president faces strong opposition in upcoming elections
Incumbent senators typically have fundraising advantages over challengers
It is incumbent upon employers to ensure workplace safety standards
The incumbent responsibility of citizenship includes jury service participation

definitions: person suffering from a disease that cannot be medically cured
person with an unchangeable characteristic or persistent behavioral trait
examples: The hospice specializes in caring for incurables with dignity
Medieval hospitals often separated incurables from other patients
He's an incurable romantic who believes in true love
My grandmother was an incurable optimist despite many hardships

definitions: act of becoming subject to something undesirable through one's actions
process of taking on debt, expenses, or liabilities
examples: Incurring debt without planning leads to financial problems later
The company risks incurring penalties for environmental violations
Incurring her father's wrath wasn't worth the minor rebellion
Athletes risk incurring injuries during intense training sessions

definitions: sudden invasion or attack on foreign territory, especially brief
unwelcome or unauthorized entry into a place or situation
examples: Border guards repelled the enemy incursion before dawn yesterday
The military incursion lasted only seventy-two hours before withdrawal
The company resisted incursions into their market share aggressively
Privacy advocates worry about government incursions into personal data

definitions: behavior or appearance considered morally offensive or inappropriate in public
quality of being offensive to accepted standards of modesty or propriety
examples: Public indecency charges were filed against the protester
The committee reviews films for indecency before television broadcast
The book was banned for alleged indecency in several districts
Standards of indecency have changed dramatically over past decades

definitions: state of being unable to make decisions quickly or effectively
examples: His indecision about college majors delayed graduation by two years
The team's indecision cost them the championship game opportunity
Chronic indecision can indicate underlying anxiety or depression issues
Her indecision frustrated colleagues who needed quick project approvals

definitions: security or protection against financial liability or loss
compensation for damage, loss, or injury suffered
examples: The insurance policy provides indemnity against earthquake damage
Professional indemnity insurance protects consultants from negligence claims
The company paid indemnity to affected customers after data breach
War reparations included indemnity payments to occupied nations

definitions: hollow, depression, or notch in a surface or edge
space at the beginning of a written or printed line
examples: The indentation in the metal showed where impact had occurred
Coastal indentations provide natural harbors for shipping vessels
Proper indentation makes computer code much easier to read
The essay required five-space indentation for each new paragraph

definitions: historical contract binding someone to work for another for a specified time
formal legal agreement or contract, especially relating to property
examples: Colonial indentures typically lasted seven years of bonded service
The museum displays original indenture documents from the eighteenth century
The property indenture specified all easements and usage restrictions clearly
Both parties signed the indenture before the notary public

definitions: state of being free from outside control or sovereign authority
ability to live or function without depending on others
examples: The nation celebrated fifty years of independence from colonial rule
The independence movement gained momentum throughout the nineteen sixties
Living alone taught her the value of financial independence
Elderly people often struggle to maintain independence as they age

definitions: person who thinks or acts free from outside influence or control
political candidate or representative not affiliated with any party
examples: She's a true independent who makes decisions based on principles
The magazine caters to independents who value original thinking
Several independents won seats in the recent parliamentary elections
The independent caucuses with Democrats but votes his conscience

definitions: quality of being uncertain, indefinite, or unable to be determined exactly
fundamental quantum mechanical principle limiting simultaneous knowledge of particle properties
examples: The indeterminacy of the outcome kept investors nervous for weeks
Legal indeterminacy allows judges considerable interpretive flexibility
Heisenberg's indeterminacy principle revolutionized our understanding of atomic behavior
Quantum indeterminacy challenges classical notions of causality and predictability

definitions: alphabetical list of topics with page references in a book
statistical measure showing changes in economy or market values
finger next to the thumb, used for pointing
examples: The textbook index helped students find specific topics quickly
She compiled a comprehensive index for the encyclopedia volume
The consumer price index rose three percent last quarter
Stock market indices reached record highs this trading session
He raised his index finger to make an important point
The child pointed with her index finger at the picture

definitions: process of creating an organized reference system for information retrieval
automatic adjustment of payments or values based on index changes
examples: Database indexing improves search query performance significantly
The librarian spent weeks indexing the archive collection properly
Pension indexing protects retirees from inflation over time
Automatic indexing of wages keeps pace with living costs

definitions: sign, signal, or piece of information suggesting something
symptom or finding suggesting a particular medical condition or treatment
examples: Early indications suggest the economy is recovering steadily
There's no indication that prices will fall anytime soon
Fever is often an indication of underlying infection
These symptoms are clear indications for immediate surgery

definitions: grammatical mood expressing statements of fact or questions
something serving as a sign or indication of something
examples: The indicative mood is used for factual statements in English
Students learned the difference between indicative and subjunctive forms
These results are indicative of broader market trends emerging
His behavior was indicative of serious underlying problems

definitions: device or gauge that shows the state or level of something
chemical substance that changes color to show pH or other conditions
statistic or data point showing the state or level of something
examples: The fuel indicator showed the tank was nearly empty
Temperature indicators help monitor engine performance continuously
Litmus paper serves as an acid-base indicator in experiments
The indicator turned pink in the alkaline solution
Economic indicators point toward continued growth this quarter
Key performance indicators track business success metrics effectively

definitions: formal written accusation charging someone with a crime
severe criticism or condemnation of someone or something
examples: The grand jury issued indictments against three company executives
Federal indictment proceedings began after the lengthy investigation concluded
The report was a damning indictment of government healthcare policy
His resignation speech included a harsh indictment of corporate culture

definitions: artist or company producing work outside major commercial organizations
artistic work produced independently of major commercial backing
examples: The indie band built a following through social media
Many indies struggle financially despite critical acclaim
That indie film won several festival awards last year
She prefers indie games over mainstream commercial releases

definitions: lack of interest, concern, or sympathy toward someone or something
examples: His indifference to her suffering shocked everyone present
Voter indifference threatens democratic participation in many countries
The manager's indifference to safety violations created dangerous conditions
She masked her hurt with an attitude of studied indifference

definitions: pain or discomfort in the stomach from difficulty digesting food
examples: Spicy foods often cause indigestion in sensitive individuals
She took antacids to relieve her chronic indigestion
Holiday overeating frequently results in uncomfortable indigestion afterwards
Stress-related indigestion affects many office workers daily

definitions: strong displeasure at something considered unjust, offensive, or insulting
examples: Public indignation over the scandal forced the minister's resignation
She expressed righteous indignation at the unfair treatment
His voice trembled with indignation as he defended himself
The community's indignation led to widespread protests and demonstrations

definitions: deep blue color between blue and violet in the spectrum
blue dye obtained from plants or produced synthetically
examples: The evening sky turned a deep indigo before nightfall
She painted the accent wall in rich indigo tones
Traditional indigo dye comes from the indigofera plant species
Japanese artisans still use natural indigo for textile dyeing

definitions: lack of control, organization, or proper behavior in individuals or groups
examples: Team indiscipline cost them the championship match decisively
The teacher struggled with widespread indiscipline in class
Financial indiscipline led to the company's eventual bankruptcy
Military indiscipline can have fatal consequences in combat situations

definitions: behavior or speech that shows lack of good judgment
act of revealing private or secret information inappropriately
examples: A momentary indiscretion ruined his political career permanently
Youthful indiscretions came back to haunt the candidate
The diplomat's indiscretion caused an international incident
Her indiscretion in sharing confidential information cost her job

definitions: single human being as distinct from a group or class
single animal, plant, or thing distinguished from others
examples: Each individual has unique talents and perspectives to offer
The rights of the individual must be balanced with society
Scientists tracked each individual in the wolf pack carefully
Every individual specimen was catalogued and labeled properly

definitions: social philosophy emphasizing individual freedom, rights, and self-reliance over collective control
examples: American individualism shapes many aspects of the nation's culture
Extreme individualism can undermine community solidarity and cooperation
The artist's fierce individualism influenced her unconventional style
Economic individualism promotes free market capitalism over regulation

definitions: person who is independent and self-reliant in thought and action
examples: She's a true individualist who follows her own path
The company culture doesn't suit individualists who prefer autonomy
Famous individualists often challenge conventional wisdom and social norms
The rugged individualist archetype features prominently in Western mythology

definitions: quality or character that distinguishes one person or thing from others
examples: The school encourages students to express their individuality creatively
Mass production threatens the individuality of handcrafted items
Her strong individuality made her stand out among peers
The architect preserved each building's historical individuality during renovation

definitions: psychological process of becoming a distinct, autonomous individual
process by which something becomes distinguished as separate and distinct
examples: Adolescent individuation from parents is a normal developmental stage
Jung considered individuation central to psychological maturity and wholeness
Cell individuation occurs during early embryonic development stages
The individuation of species happens through evolutionary processes

definitions: process of teaching someone to accept beliefs uncritically
systematic instruction in fundamentals or doctrines of a belief system
examples: Critics accused the program of political indoctrination of students
Religious indoctrination often begins in early childhood years
Military indoctrination transforms civilians into disciplined soldiers effectively
The cult used sleep deprivation during member indoctrination processes

definitions: thing that persuades or influences someone to do something
act of persuading or influencing someone to take action
examples: Financial inducements attracted skilled workers to remote locations
The company offered stock options as inducement for retention
No amount of inducement could change her mind about leaving
Bribery involves illegal inducement of public officials

definitions: act of bringing about or causing something to happen
medical process of artificially starting labor and childbirth
examples: The medication has side effects including inducing drowsiness
Scientists are inducing mutations to study genetic diseases
The doctor recommended inducing labor due to complications
They're inducing delivery two weeks before the due date

definitions: person who is formally admitted into an organization or position
person inducted into military service, especially through draft
examples: Hall of Fame inductees receive bronze plaques honoring achievements
The newest inductees underwent orientation training this week
Vietnam War inductees often faced difficult moral choices
Military inductees reported to the processing center at dawn

definitions: formal process of introducing someone to a new position or organization
inference of general principles from specific observations or instances
production of electric current or magnetism by proximity to charged or magnetized body
examples: The induction ceremony welcomed fifty new members yesterday
Employee induction programs help newcomers adjust to company culture
Scientific induction builds theories from repeated experimental observations
Mathematical induction proves statements true for all natural numbers
Electromagnetic induction powers most electrical generators and transformers
Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction in eighteen thirty-one

definitions: act of allowing oneself to enjoy pleasure, especially excessively
attitude of being lenient, permissive, or tolerant
Roman Catholic practice of reducing punishment for sins
examples: Chocolate cake was her favorite indulgence after stressful days
The spa weekend was an expensive but necessary indulgence
Parents worry their indulgence might spoil the children
The teacher's indulgence of tardiness upset punctual students
Medieval churches sold indulgences to fund construction projects
Luther protested the sale of indulgences in his theses

definitions: act of allowing oneself to enjoy something pleasurable
act of allowing someone to have or do what they want
examples: Indulging in dessert occasionally won't ruin your diet
She spent the weekend indulging in her favorite hobbies
Stop indulging his tantrums with constant attention and rewards
Grandparents enjoy indulging their grandchildren with treats and gifts

definitions: person who owns or manages an industrial enterprise or enterprises
examples: Nineteenth-century industrialists built vast fortunes from steel and railways
The industrialist donated millions to establish the university
Modern industrialists focus on automation and sustainable manufacturing practices
Local industrialists met to discuss regional economic development strategies

definitions: economic activity concerned with processing raw materials and manufacturing
particular form or branch of productive or profit-making enterprise
quality of working hard and steadily
examples: The automotive industry employs millions of workers worldwide
Heavy industry declined as the economy shifted toward services
The film industry generates billions in revenue annually
She works in the hospitality industry managing boutique hotels
His industry and dedication earned him rapid promotion
The student's industry impressed all her professors greatly

definitions: state of not achieving maximum productivity or optimal results
instance of wasteful or ineffective use of resources
examples: Bureaucratic inefficiency delays important government services and programs
The audit revealed shocking inefficiency in procurement processes
Energy inefficiency in older buildings increases operational costs significantly
Market inefficiency creates opportunities for arbitrage and profit

definitions: state of not meeting requirements or qualifications for something
examples: His criminal record resulted in ineligibility for government positions
Academic ineligibility prevented several athletes from competing this season
The company contested their ineligibility for federal contracts unsuccessfully
Age ineligibility disqualified her from the youth program
